title: Harmony Township, New Jersey
text:
Harmony Township is a <a href="Township%20%28New%20Jersey%29">township</a> located in the far eastern region of the <a href="Lehigh%20Valley">Lehigh Valley</a> in <a href="Warren%20County%2C%20New%20Jersey">Warren County</a>, <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a>, United States. As of the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 United States Census</a>, the township's population was 2,667, reflecting a decline of 62 (-2.3%) from the 2,729 counted in the <a href="2000%20United%20States%20Census">2000 Census</a>, which had in turn increased by 76 (+2.9%) from the 2,653 counted in the <a href="1990%20United%20States%20Census">1990 Census</a>.
Harmony was incorporated as a township by an act of the <a href="New%20Jersey%20Legislature">New Jersey Legislature</a> on April 8, 1839, from portions of <a href="Greenwich%20Township%2C%20Warren%20County%2C%20New%20Jersey">Greenwich Township</a> and <a href="Oxford%20Township%2C%20New%20Jersey">Oxford Township</a>, based on the results of a referendum held that day. <a href="Phillipsburg%2C%20New%20Jersey">Phillipsburg Township</a> was created March 7, 1851, from portions of the township. The township was named for Harmon Shipman, an early settler.
Geography.
According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, Harmony township had a total area of 24.13 square miles (62.49 km2), including 23.75 square miles (61.51 km2) of land and 0.38 square miles (0.98 km2) of water (1.56%).
<a href="Brainards%2C%20New%20Jersey">Brainards</a> (with a 2010 Census population of 202), <a href="Harmony%20%28CDP%29%2C%20New%20Jersey">Harmony CDP</a> (441) and <a href="Hutchinson%2C%20New%20Jersey">Hutchinson</a> (135) are <a href="Local%20government%20in%20New%20Jersey%23Unincorporated%20communities">unincorporated communities</a> and <a href="census-designated%20place">census-designated place</a>s (CDPs) located within the township.
Other unincorporated communities, localities and place names located partially or completely within the township include Allens Mills, Harmony Station, Lower Harmony, Martins Creek Station, <a href="Montana%2C%20New%20Jersey">Montana</a> and Roxburg.
The township borders the Warren County municipalities of <a href="Franklin%20Township%2C%20Warren%20County%2C%20New%20Jersey">Franklin Township</a>, <a href="Lopatcong%20Township%2C%20New%20Jersey">Lopatcong Township</a> and <a href="White%20Township%2C%20New%20Jersey">White Township</a>.
Demographics.
The Township's economic data (as is all of Warren County) is calculated by the US Census Bureau as part of the <a href="Lehigh%20Valley">Allentown-Bethlehem-Easton, PA-NJ Metropolitan Statistical Area</a>.
Census 2010.
 The Census Bureau's 2006-2010 <a href="American%20Community%20Survey">American Community Survey</a> showed that (in 2010 <a href="inflation%20adjustment">inflation-adjusted</a> dollars) <a href="median%20household%20income">median household income</a> was $82,339 (with a margin of error of +/- $7,992) and the median family income was $86,964 (+/- $11,141). Males had a median income of $60,489 (+/- $4,798) versus $53,100 (+/- $11,618) for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the borough was $34,985 (+/- $4,062). About 0.7% of families and 1.2% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 0.5% of those under age 18 and 1.7% of those age 65 or over.
Census 2000.
As of the <a href="2000%20United%20States%20Census">2000 United States Census</a> there were 2,729 people, 1,010 households, and 786 families residing in the township. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was 114.6 people per square mile (44.3/km2). There were 1,076 housing units at an average density of 45.2 per square mile (17.4/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 97.91% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 0.70% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.07% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.40% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.18% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 0.73% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race were 1.28% of the population.
There were 1,010 households, out of which 34.2% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 66.3% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 7.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 22.1% were non-families. 17.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.68 and the average family size was 3.05.
In the township the population was spread out, with 24.1% under the age of 18, 5.2% from 18 to 24, 30.6% from 25 to 44, 26.2% from 45 to 64, and 13.9% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.2 males.
The median income for a household in the township was $60,977, and the median income for a family was $64,196. Males had a median income of $49,375 versus $28,750 for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the township was $25,776. About 2.8% of families and 4.5% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 3.9% of those under age 18 and 5.3% of those age 65 or over.
Government.
Local government.
Harmony Township is governed under the <a href="Township%20%28New%20Jersey%29">Township</a> form of New Jersey municipal government, one of 141 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this form, the second-most commonly used form of government in the state. The governing body is comprised of a three-member Township Committee, whose members are elected directly by the voters <a href="at-large">at-large</a> in partisan elections to serve three-year terms of office on a staggered basis, with one seat coming up for election each year as part of the November general election in a three-year cycle. At an annual reorganization meeting, the Township Committee selects one of its members to serve as Mayor.
, members of the Harmony Township Committee are <a href="Mayor">Mayor</a> Brian R. Tipton (<a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">R</a>, term on committee ends December 31, 2021; term as mayor ends 2020), <a href="Deputy%20Mayor">Deputy Mayor</a> Diane Yamrock (R, term on committee and as deputy mayor ends 2020) and Richard T. Cornely (R, 2022).
Federal, state and county representation.
Harmony Township is located in the 7th Congressional District and is part of New Jersey's 23rd state legislative district. Prior to the 2010 Census, Harmony Township had been part of the , a change made by the <a href="New%20Jersey%20Redistricting%20Commission">New Jersey Redistricting Commission</a> that took effect in January 2013, based on the results of the November 2012 general elections.
Politics.
As of March 23, 2011, there were a total of 1,802 registered voters in Harmony Township, of which 333 (18.5% vs. 21.5% countywide) were registered as <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrats</a>, 786 (43.6% vs. 35.3%) were registered as <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republicans</a> and 683 (37.9% vs. 43.1%) were registered as <a href="Unaffiliated%20%28New%20Jersey%29">Unaffiliated</a>. There were no voters registered to other parties. Among the township's 2010 Census population, 67.6% (vs. 62.3% in Warren County) were registered to vote, including 85.5% of those ages 18 and over (vs. 81.5% countywide).
In the <a href="United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20New%20Jersey%2C%202012">2012 presidential election</a>, Republican <a href="Mitt%20Romney">Mitt Romney</a> received 702 votes (58.9% vs. 56.0% countywide), ahead of Democrat <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> with 442 votes (37.1% vs. 40.8%) and other candidates with 24 votes (2.0% vs. 1.7%), among the 1,192 ballots cast by the township's 1,826 registered voters, for a turnout of 65.3% (vs. 66.7% in Warren County). In the <a href="United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20New%20Jersey%2C%202008">2008 presidential election</a>, Republican <a href="John%20McCain">John McCain</a> received 805 votes (59.9% vs. 55.2% countywide), ahead of Democrat Barack Obama with 486 votes (36.1% vs. 41.4%) and other candidates with 33 votes (2.5% vs. 1.6%), among the 1,345 ballots cast by the township's 1,824 registered voters, for a turnout of 73.7% (vs. 73.4% in Warren County). In the <a href="United%20States%20presidential%20election%20in%20New%20Jersey%2C%202004">2004 presidential election</a>, Republican <a href="George%20W.%20Bush">George W. Bush</a> received 798 votes (61.6% vs. 61.0% countywide), ahead of Democrat <a href="John%20Kerry">John Kerry</a> with 479 votes (37.0% vs. 37.2%) and other candidates with 14 votes (1.1% vs. 1.3%), among the 1,296 ballots cast by the township's 1,713 registered voters, for a turnout of 75.7% (vs. 76.3% in the whole county).
In the <a href="New%20Jersey%20gubernatorial%20election%2C%202013">2013 gubernatorial election</a>, Republican <a href="Chris%20Christie">Chris Christie</a> received 75.9% of the vote (536 cast), ahead of Democrat <a href="Barbara%20Buono">Barbara Buono</a> with 21.4% (151 votes), and other candidates with 2.7% (19 votes), among the 717 ballots cast by the township's 1,844 registered voters (11 ballots were spoiled), for a turnout of 38.9%. In the <a href="New%20Jersey%20gubernatorial%20election%2C%202009">2009 gubernatorial election</a>, Republican Chris Christie received 543 votes (63.7% vs. 61.3% countywide), ahead of Democrat <a href="Jon%20Corzine">Jon Corzine</a> with 197 votes (23.1% vs. 25.7%), Independent <a href="Chris%20Daggett">Chris Daggett</a> with 84 votes (9.9% vs. 9.8%) and other candidates with 11 votes (1.3% vs. 1.5%), among the 852 ballots cast by the township's 1,800 registered voters, yielding a 47.3% turnout (vs. 49.6% in the county).
Education.
The <a href="Harmony%20Township%20School%20District">Harmony Township School District</a> serves students in public school for <a href="pre-kindergarten">pre-kindergarten</a> through <a href="eighth%20grade">eighth grade</a> at Harmony Township School. As of the 2018–19 school year, the district, comprised of one school, had an enrollment of 243 students and 33.0 classroom teachers (on an <a href="full-time%20equivalent">FTE</a> basis), for a <a href="student%E2%80%93teacher%20ratio">student–teacher ratio</a> of 7.4:1. In 2006, a Harmony student won the state spelling bee becoming the first Harmony student ever to accomplish that task and advance to the <a href="Scripps%20National%20Spelling%20Bee">Scripps National Spelling Bee</a>.
Public school students in <a href="ninth%20grade">ninth</a> through <a href="twelfth%20grade">twelfth grade</a>s from Harmony, <a href="Hope%20Township%2C%20New%20Jersey">Hope</a> and <a href="White%20Township%2C%20New%20Jersey">White</a> Townships attend <a href="Belvidere%20High%20School%20%28New%20Jersey%29">Belvidere High School</a> as part of <a href="sending/receiving%20relationship">sending/receiving relationship</a>s with the <a href="Belvidere%20School%20District">Belvidere School District</a>. As of the 2018–19 school year, the high school had an enrollment of 420 students and 38.3 classroom teachers (on an <a href="full-time%20equivalent">FTE</a> basis), for a <a href="student%E2%80%93teacher%20ratio">student–teacher ratio</a> of 11.0:1.
Students from the township and from all of Warren County are eligible to attend Ridge and Valley Charter School in <a href="Frelinghuysen%20Township%2C%20New%20Jersey">Frelinghuysen Township</a> (for grades K-8) or <a href="Warren%20County%20Technical%20School">Warren County Technical School</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20New%20Jersey">Washington borough</a> (for 9-12), with special education services provided by local districts supplemented throughout the county by the <a href="Warren%20County%20Special%20Services%20School%20District">Warren County Special Services School District</a> in <a href="Oxford%20Township%2C%20New%20Jersey">Oxford Township</a> (for PreK-12).
Transportation.
, the township had a total of of roadways, of which were maintained by the municipality and by Warren County.
The only major road that traverses Harmony is <a href="County%20Route%20519%20%28New%20Jersey%29">CR 519</a>, which leads to <a href="U.S.%20Route%2022%20in%20New%20Jersey">U.S. Route 22</a> to the south and <a href="U.S.%20Route%2046">U.S. Route 46</a> to the north.
The closest limited access road is <a href="Interstate%2078%20in%20New%20Jersey">Interstate 78</a> which is in neighboring Greenwich and Franklin.
Notable people.
People who were born in, residents of, or otherwise closely associated with Harmony Township include:
